ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Fundamental emission characteristics of light-emitting liquid crystal cells with rubrene-doped 4-cyano-4’-pentylbiphenyl

Affiliation.OrgDivision: Department of Electronics and Information Systems, Faculty of Systems Science and Technology

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: We have investigated the light emission properties in rubrene-doped nematic liquid crystal (LC) cells from the following three standpoints: (i) effect of the heating temperature during the sample preparation, (ii) role of the emissive LC layer thickness, and (iii) role of different LC types used as the emissive layer. As a result, the light-emitting LC cells simultaneously exhibit the features of electrochemiluminescent cells (the carrier transport is governed by an ionic conduction) as well as of organic light-emitting diodes (the luminance strongly depends on the emissive layer thickness). Furthermore, we report that devices with cyano group containing LCs exhibit higher luminance compared to a fluorinated LC.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: There has been increasing interest in light-emitting devices having soft-matter and solution-based emissive layers [1–19], including liquid crystal (LC) semiconductors [4, 7, 10], liquid semiconductors [13, 17, 18], conjugated polymer-containing electrolytes [2, 9], and ionic liquids [15, 16]. These materials are of particular interest because of their high degree of flexibility, simple device fabrication processes, large-area processing capabilities, and their pinhole-free nature. Among the earliest solution-based light-emitting devices were electrochemiluminescent (ECL) cells [1], with fluorescent dye-doped organic solvents used as the emissive layer. Light-emitting electrochemical (LEC) cells [2, 9] are unique devices that have a dynamically formed p-i-n structure in their emissive layers. The use of a fluorescent dye-doped liquid semiconductor is another very interesting method [13]. In contrast to isotropic emissive materials, LC emissive layers have been introduced to offer polarized light emission, which arises from the self-organized molecular orientation of LCs [4, 7, 10, 14, 19]. Thus far, many smectic and discotic LCs have been shown to exhibit semiconducting characteristics, owing to their high degree of molecular ordering and good molecular packing capabilities. Unlike the smectic and discotic LCs, the molecular orientation of nematic LCs is easily controlled by an external field. Furthermore, the reorientation induced by the field can be maintained even when the emissive layer is bent. Therefore, nematic LC-based light-emitting devices can potentially be used in flexible devices that feature polarized emission.

To date, the electrochemiluminescence from nematic liquid crystal 4-cyano-4′-pentylbiphenyl (5CB) doped with 5,6,11,12-tetraphenylnaphthacene (rubrene) (Fig. 1) has been briefly studied [20]. Additionally, the light emission characteristics from nematic LC cells, comprising a 5CB emissive layer with an iridium complex (phosphorescent dye), have been reported [21]. Furthermore, we have demonstrated the emission of weakly polarized light from light-emitting LC (LE-LC) cells with a nematic LC (5CB) doped with a fluorescent dye (rubrene); the polarization direction of the emitted light could be electrically switched by changing the direction of a laterally applied electric field [14]. A luminance of over 100 cd/cm2 was obtained by the introduction of a heating stir process during the dissolution of the rubrene [14]. To further improve the device performance, a greater insight into the operational principles is required. To achieve this, an understanding of the basic light-emission characteristics is essential. Here, we investigated the role of the following three factors in defining the characteristics of light emission: (i) the temperature during the heating stir process, (ii) the emissive LC layer thickness, and (iii) the different types of LCs that are used as the emissive layer.
Fig. 1
Chemical structures of 5CB (nematic LC) and rubrene (fluorescent dye)

Section1.Heading: Influence of heating temperature on device performance

Section2.Heading: Actual rubrene concentration in the LC emissive layer
Section2.Para: Rubrene was used in the LE-LC cells as an emissive material that exhibits a high fluorescence efficiency in a dilute solvent. The phenyl group attached to the tetracene core prevents the formation of a dimer, and subsequently suppresses concentration quenching. We have previously reported that the heating temperature during the rubrene dissolution process improves the device performance; specifically, the maximal luminance is improved as the applied voltage increases [14]. In this section, we will discuss the influence of the heating temperature on the device performance.

In a sample preparation, a rubrene powder was directly mixed with a nematic LC (5CB). The mixing fraction of rubrene was adjusted to be ∼1.0 wt% (∼0.019 mol/L). The mixed specimen was pre-stirred at room temperature for 4 h, followed by the primary stir at 30 °C increments between 40 and 130 °C; hereafter, we refer to this procedure as the heating stir process. Sample LC cells had a structure that was similar to that of conventional sandwich-type LC cells; that is, the doped LC was injected into an empty cell with two glass substrates, the surfaces of which had been covered with polyimide films (SE150; Nissan Chemical Industry). Before constructing the empty cell, the polyimide films were heated at 200 °C for 1 h and then unidirectionally rubbed in order to induce a homogeneous orientation of LC. The gap between the two substrates was controlled by using a glass rod or polymer ball spacers. Finally, the injected cell was sealed using an epoxy resin.

The fabricated cells were first inspected using an optical microscope to examine the dissolution quality of the rubrene powder, as shown in Fig. 2, where the LC layer thickness was ∼20 μm. The temperature at the heating stir process is indicated in each image. All optical microscopy observations were carried out at room temperature. As can be seen from Fig. 2, an aggregation of tiny rubrene particles was formed in the samples processed at a lower heating temperature. Judging from the images for the unheated and 40 °C-heated samples, the amount of the undissolved rubrene particles seemed to be constant. The undissolved rubrene particles tended to decrease as the heating temperature exceeded 40 °C and almost completely disappeared in the 100 °C- and 130 °C-heated samples. This extinction behavior indicates that the dissolution of rubrene particles was facilitated by heating. In other words, the actual rubrene concentration, which depended on the heating temperature, was different from the mixed fraction (apparent concentration) of rubrene.
Fig. 2
Optical microscope images of homogeneous LC cells with rubrene-doped 5CB. The fraction of mixed rubrene (apparent concentration) was ∼1.0 wt% and the LC layer thickness was 20 μm. Note that the temperature indicated in each one of the images denotes the temperature at the heating stir process. All of the measurements were carried out at room temperature

In order to confirm this hypothesis, we evaluated the optical density of the sample cell, as shown in Fig. 3(a). During the evaluation process, the absorption spectrum was measured, followed by the calculation of the transmittance that was averaged in the range from 480 to 520 nm. The optical density was calculated using the equation logT −1, where T is the averaged transmittance. For the accurate evaluation of the optical density, the reflection loss of the glass surface and the scattering loss caused by a thermal fluctuation of LC were corrected for by using undoped reference cells to establish the baseline. From Fig. 3(a) it is clear that the optical density is proportional to the LC layer thickness d. This characteristic is well explained by the Beer–Lambert law: 1
$$ \log T^{-1} = \varepsilon Cd, $$ where ε is the molar absorptivity and C is the molar concentration. Therefore, the slope in Fig. 3(a) is identical to the product εC. Provided that the molar absorptivity is independent of the heating temperature; the quantity εC represents the relative concentration of the dissolved rubrene. As is evident from Fig. 3(b), εC was constant for heating temperatures lower than 40 °C and gradually increased as the heating temperature exceeded 40 °C. This characteristic is consistent with our results obtained from microscopy observations that are shown in Fig. 2.
Fig. 3
(a) Relationship between the optical density and the LC layer thickness for different heating temperatures. All of the measurements were carried out at room temperature. The fraction of mixed rubrene was ∼1.0 wt%. (b) Relationship between εC and the heating temperature, where ε is a molar absorptivity and C is an actual rubrene concentration

Section2.Heading: Light-emission properties of LE-LC cells
Section2.Para: We examined the light-emitting properties of LE-LC cells with rubrene-doped 5CB, which were processed under different heating temperatures. The structure of the fabricated LE-LC cell was similar to that of general sandwich-type LC cells. One of the two glass substrate surfaces was covered with an Al layer (<100 nm), deposited by the vacuum evaporation method. The spin-coating method was used to coat the opposite substrate surface with EDOT:PSS [poly(3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene): poly(styrenesulfonate)] (∼20 nm). The gap between the two substrates was controlled using the glass rod spacer with a diameter of 6 μm. The injected LC material (mixed fraction: 2 wt%) was prepared in the same manner as described in Sect. 2.1. The edge of the injected cell was sealed with an epoxy resin.

Figures 4(a) and (b), shows the dependence of the current density and the luminance, respectively, on the electric field strength. In order to eliminate the influence of small variations in thickness among the test cells, the current density and the luminance were plotted versus the electric field rather than being plotted against the applied voltage. All of the measurements were carried out at room temperature. From Figs. 4(a) and (b), both the current density and the luminance are found to drastically increase with an increasing strength of the electric field. It is notable that the J–E and L–E curves for the different heating temperatures are almost identical regardless of the temperature. As shown in Fig. 3(b), the actual rubrene concentration increases with the increasing heating temperature. However, Fig. 4(a) shows that the current density is independent of the heating temperature (the actual rubrene concentration), suggesting that the carrier transport is governed by the ionic conduction. If a hopping conduction was dominant, the current density would be expected to depend on the rubrene density. The external quantum efficiency (EQE) is also shown to be almost independent of the heating temperature [see the inset of Fig. 4(b)]. The EQE is observed to steeply increase for electric fields stronger than ∼50 kV/cm (∼30 V for d=6 μm), suggesting that the positive and negative carriers balance with the increased applied voltage.
Fig. 4
(a) Current density and (b) luminance, versus the applied electric field, for different heating temperatures. All of the measurements were carried out at room temperature. The inset shows the dependence of the external quantum efficiency on the electric field strength. The fraction of mixed rubrene was 2.0 wt% and the diameter of the spacer was 6 μm

According to our previously presented energy diagram [22], the energy gap (0.4 eV) between the HOMO level of rubrene (5.4 eV) and the work function of PEDOT (5.0 eV) is much smaller than that (1.1 eV) between the LUMO level (3.2 eV) of rubrene and the work function of Al (4.3 eV). This suggests that hole injection (oxidization) is more frequent than electron injection (reduction). Therefore, we consider that hole injection is observed first, followed by electron injection as the applied electric field increases. This indicates that EQE increases with an increase in the applied electric field. The exact reason for the steep increase in EQE when the electric field exceeds ∼50 kV/cm is unclear at this stage. However, we suggest that EQE may be improved by the flow of 5CB solvent that is induced by the migration of cations and anions under a strong electric field. It has been pointed out that a stirring effect of generated radical ions in a solvent can facilitate efficient exciton formations [20].

Next, we briefly discuss the relationship between the light-emission properties and the rubrene concentration, as shown in Fig. 5. Here, ΔQ in
$( = \int_{0}^{t_{m}} Q_{\mathrm{in }}( t )\,dt )$ is the charge per cm2 that is generated until the current density reaches its maximal value. ΔQ out
$(=\int_{0}^{t_{m}}EQE\times Q_{\mathrm{in}}(t)\,dt)$ is the charge consumed for the light emission, where t m is the time for the maximum luminance when the voltage applying rate was 1.25 V/s; Q in is the charge that flowed into the device per cm2 per second. Figure 5 reveals that the generated and consumed charges (ΔQ in and ΔQ out, respectively) linearly increase as the actual rubrene concentration is increased. Namely, the total amount of the rubrene content is a critical factor in determining how much light can be emitted by the LE-LC cell. In other words, a possible explanation for the appearance of maximal values of current density and luminance is the deterioration of the dissolved rubrene molecule in the 5CB solvent. In contrast to that observed in a general organic light-emitting diode (OLED), the organic molecules, as radical cations and anions, are sufficiently mobile in the LE-LC cells. This leads to an undesirable side reaction. Therefore, the lifetime of the device is much shorter than that of a general OLED. A typical lifetime (the time required for the luminance to decay to half of its maximum) was ∼30 min when the concentration was 2 wt%, the heating temperature was 100 °C (for 15 min), the LC layer thickness was 6 μm, and the applied voltage was 100 V.
Fig. 5
Total amount of the generated charge, ΔQ in, and consumed charge, ΔQ out, versus εC, plotted up to the point at which the current density reaches its maximal value. Closed and open symbols denote ΔQ in and ΔQ out, respectively. The fraction of mixed rubrene was 2.0 wt% and the diameter of the spacer was 6 μm

Section1.Heading: Influence of LC layer thickness on device performance
Section1.Para: As was mentioned in the previous Section, the current density and the luminance are independent of the rubrene concentration. Accordingly, ionic conduction is dominant in the LE-LC cells. In a general ECL cell, in which ionic current is mainly generated, the current is independent of the layer thickness. In contrast, OLEDs in general exhibit a strong thickness dependence. This difference stems from the fact that the voltage is mostly applied at the interface between the electrode and the organic layer in ECL cells, and the generated carriers (ions) move based on the diffusion phenomenon. Therefore, the current in the ECL cells exhibits minimal dependence on the thickness of the emissive layer [1]. However, the voltage is applied across the organic bulk layer itself in OLEDs, hence the reason for the greater dependence of the current on the thickness of the emissive layer.

Figures 6(a) and (b), shows the dependence of the current density and the luminance on the voltage, for different values of LC layer thickness. In the examined cells, we used Al cathodes and PEDOT anodes. The apparent rubrene concentration (mixed fraction of rubrene) was 2 wt%. The mixed specimen was heated at 100 °C for 15 min during the heating stir process. The cell was fabricated in the same manner as described in Sect. 2. As is evident from Fig. 6, both the current density and the luminance strongly depend on the LC layer thickness. On the other hand, the current density—electric field and the luminance—electric field curves (J–E and L–E curves) for different LC layer thickness are similar, as shown in the insets (Fig. 6), indicating that almost all of the voltage is applied across the LC layer (bulk). This is interesting because this feature is similar to what is observed in OLEDs, although the carrier transport here is governed by ionic conduction like in the ECL cells. Therefore, our LE-LC cells should be categorized as being between OLEDs and ECL cells.
Fig. 6
(a) Current density and (b) luminance, versus voltage, for different levels of LC layer thickness. The insets show the current density and the luminance versus the electric field strength. The fraction of mixed rubrene was 2 wt% and the heating stir process was carried out at 100 °C for 15 min

Section1.Heading: Influence of LC’s functional group on device performance
Section1.Para: The positive and negative carriers (the radical cation and anion) generated in the LC layer tend to be naturally reduced in numbers. Some of these carriers are neutralized through the formation of excitons (light emission), some reach the counter electrode without the exciton formation, and some may be consumed through the undesirable side reaction. In order to improve the performance of the device, we have to prevent the radical ions from being consumed by the side reaction. One solution is to stabilize the radical cations by mixing an appropriate additive with the solution. For example, in the ECL cells with rubrene-doped mixed solvent (o-dichlorobenzene and acetonitrile), the luminance and the current density are dramatically improved by doping with 1,2-diphenoxyethane [23]. This reported dopant solvates the generated radical cations to make them stable.

It is natural for the different LC solvents to create different degrees of stability for the generated cations. We examined light-emission properties of LE-LC cells with different types of nematic LCs; that is, 5CB, ZLI-1132 (Merck), and ZLI-5092 (Merck). 5CB is a well-known cyanobiphenyl nematic LC consisting of a single chemical compound. ZLI-1132 is a nematic mixture containing cyanobiphenyl compounds [24]. ZLI-5092 is a fluorinated nematic LC. The J–E and L–E characteristics are shown in Figs. 7(a) and (b), respectively. The mixed rubrene fraction was 2 wt%. The heating stir process was carried out at 100 °C for 1 h. Figures 7(a) and (b), reveals that the cyanobiphenyl-containing nematic LCs obviously exhibit better current density and luminance characteristics compared with the fluorinated nematic LCs. The 5CB- or ZLI-1132-containing LE-LC cell begins to operate at a lower electric field than that required for the operation of a ZLI-5092-containing LE-LC cell. We presume that the radical cation is stabilized by the LC’s cyano group with strong electron acceptability. In fact, the cyano group containing LC is generally easy to solvate ionic impurities, leading to the fact that it is difficult to obtain cyanobiphenyl LCs with a very high degree of purity. On the other hand, it is considered that ionic impurities are not incorporated in fluorinated LCs compared with cyanobiphenyl LCs, offering a higher voltage holding ratio than that for the cyanobiphenyl LCs in thin-film-transistor LC displays.
Fig. 7
Plots of (a) the current density and (b) the luminance for different LC solvents, versus the electric field strength. The fraction of mixed rubrene was 2 wt%. The heating stir process was carried out at 100 °C for 1 h

Section1.Heading: Conclusions
Section1.Para: We have investigated the fundamental light-emission properties of LE-LC cells in which the rubrene-doped 5CB nematic LC was used as an emissive layer. The influences of the following three factors are discussed: (i) the temperature during the heating stir process, (ii) the emissive LC layer thickness, and (iii) the different types of LCs used as the emissive layer. Regarding (i), the rubrene concentration increased with the increasing heating temperature at the time of the sample preparation. However, the increase in the concentration by heating was found to have no effect on the current density and the luminance characteristics, indicating that the carrier transport process is governed not by hopping conduction but by the ionic conduction. With respect to (ii), the voltage dependencies of the current density and the luminance curves were shown to be affected by the emissive layer thickness, while the electric field dependencies were similar for the layers of different thickness. This feature is characteristic of OLEDs. The LE-LC cells simultaneously exhibit both features of ECL cells (the ionic conduction) and OLEDs (the thickness dependence). Regarding (iii), the light emission properties in the devices with the cyano group containing LC were better than those observed for the fluorinated LC. We suggest that strong electron acceptability of the cyano group tends to stabilize the rubrene cation.
